# Ethical Governance of AI in Global Health

## Abstract
The ethical governance of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in health care and public health continues to be an urgent issue for attention in policy, research, and practice. This paper reports on central themes related to challenges and strategies for promoting ethics in research involving AI in global health research, arising from the Global Forum on Bioethics in Research (GFBR), held in Cape Town, South Africa in November 2022. We highlight categories of ethical issues emphasized at the forum and outline strategies proposed for research, innovation, and governance to support more ethical AI for global health.

# Ethical Governance of AI in Global Health Research

## Abstract
One important point emphasized in the WHO report that reinforces the broader literature on global governance of AI is the distribution of responsibility across a wide range of actors in the AI ecosystem. This is especially important to highlight when focused on research for global health, which is specifically about work that transcends national borders. Alami et al. (2020) discussed the unique risks raised by AI research in global health, ranging from the unavailability of data in many LMICs required to train locally relevant AI models to the capacity of health systems to absorb new AI technologies that demand the use of resources from elsewhere in the system. These observations illustrate the need to identify the unique issues posed by AI research for global health specifically, and the strategies that can be employed by all those implicated in AI governance to promote ethically responsible use of AI in global health ...

# Ethical Governance of AI in Global Health Research

## Abstract
This paper synthesizes the challenges and opportunities raised at the Global Forum on Bioethics in Research (GFBR) meeting, focusing on the ethical implications of AI in global health research. We aim to highlight central issues, proposed solutions, and the challenges facing the research ethics community, particularly in low-resource settings.

## Introduction
The GFBR meeting serves as a platform for policymakers, Research Ethics Committee (REC) members, and other stakeholders to engage with the challenges and opportunities related to research ethics. Each year, the forum includes case studies and keynote presentations, followed by small-group discussions aimed at advancing thinking on related issues. The topics of past forums have included ethical issues in research with individuals living with mental health conditions, genome editing, and biobanking/data sharing. ## Abstract
The paper discusses the ethical governance of artificial intelligence (AI) in global health research, highlighting the complexities and challenges faced by researchers and institutions. It emphasizes the need for a nuanced understanding of consent, accountability, and the transferability of AI systems across different health contexts.

It sets the stage for a discussion on the role of Research Ethics Committees (RECs) and the importance of ethical governance in ensuring responsible AI deployment.

# Ethical Governance of AI in Global Health Research

## Abstract
The paper discusses the ethical governance challenges posed by the development and implementation of AI technologies in global health research. It summarizes insights from the 2022 Global Forum on Bioethics in Research (GFBR), focusing on thematic challenges and suggestions for improving governance in this area.

## Introduction
Research involving AI technologies in global health is rapidly increasing, raising significant ethical governance challenges. This paper aims to summarize insights from the GFBR, particularly regarding research ethics related to AI in global health.

## Methods
The insights presented in this paper were derived from discussions and presentations at the 2022 GFBR, where participants shared their perspectives on the ethical governance of AI in global health research.

# Ethical Governance of AI in Global Health Research

## Abstract
This paper discusses the challenges and strategies for the ethical governance of artificial intelligence (AI) in global health research. It highlights the rapid evolution of AI technologies and the need for governance leaders to adapt their approaches accordingly. The paper emphasizes the importance of international collaboration within the research ethics community to enhance governance capabilities.

## Introduction
The introduction outlines the significance of AI in global health research and the ethical implications that arise from its use. It sets the stage for discussing the governance challenges and the need for effective strategies to address them.
